ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You do a deep dive into paradise lost and a few other of milton's texts

This class focuses on Milton's Paradise Lost, with supplementary readings in his selected prose, sonnets, and shorter poetry, as well as his closet drama Samson Agonistes. You come away with a good understanding of the primary texts and the questions they raise. Assignments entail close reading.
I learnt a lot about Milton's Paradise Lost and the texts surrounding it.

This course was an extended close reading of Paradise Lost over 12 weeks. We discussed the text in seminar, along with some supplementary readings about Milton's historical milieu, the English Civil War, and Milton criticism.
Reading very deeply, appreciating the resonances between Milton's other works (Samson Agonistes, Lycidas, Doctrine and Discipline of Divorce) and the poem

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: i think that this course could have benefited from reading more of milton's other texts and shouldn't have assumed religious or physics foreknowledge

A strength of this course is the material. Milton, love or hate him, is really fascinating and has a lot to say about everything, which is conducive to a seminar -- there's always something to comment on and explore. I think Professor Mohamed did an excellent job guiding the discussion and pointing us to specific passages.
The weekly discussions were very long which was very conducive to having long and complex discussions about the text.

I thought that Professor Mohamed and Clay did a great job leading the seminar, although some weeks it felt like it moved more towards them leading it when students had been assigned to lead (which wasn't necessarily a bad thing, every person having to lead 2-3 weeks of discussion is a lot!)

Could have more organic student participation -- the first half often felt like a lecture before the student discussion leaders for the day took over, if they took over at all -- but the professor is extremely knowledgeable

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really liked that Professor Mohammed would give us breaks during the seminar
The small class size really helped to preserve the sense of a seminar even though the class was online.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think if you LOVE milton than yes, but i would brush up on genesis beforehand

This course is great if you're an English major or are interested in reading a great, important literary text. Professor Mohamed is great at leading class and it was fairly lowkey and not a significant amount of work -- just 2 short, 3-page essays and then a 10-page final paper.
Yes, understanding Paradise Lost is difficult but very rewarding since it gives a good view or entry point into early modern poetry.

Yes, Paradise Lost is an incredible work of literature, and I think there's something in it for everyone to appreciate, even if they aren't religious, an English major, etc. It's a difficult text but there isn't too much work in this class other than the reading, 2 short essays, and a final paper, so if Paradise Lost has been on your bucket list, this is a great way to explore it!
Yes!! I love paradise lost and this was a great class to explore it!!

As someone who took the course because it was the one Renaissance credit offered this semester, I would say yes to those in a similar situation, but I don't know if I would necessarily recommend it overall. If you love Paradise Lost and/or Milton, or you are interested in the experience of reading one difficult poem very deeply with the guidance of an experienced professor, then you will enjoy it. If you need a Renaissance credit, this is also a fairly painless way to get it. I appreciated the course overall, but if you don't fit either of those categories, I don't think the course is impactful enough to warrant taking it over another.
